intro: Turpinia venosa, commonly known as the Hawaiian elder or kāhui, is a shrub native to the Hawaiian Islands. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its woody stems and opposite, ovate leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are clustered in dense inflorescences, followed by capsule fruits containing numerous seeds. It thrives in coastal and lowland habitats, often growing in dry, sunny areas. Turpinia venosa is an important part of Hawaii's native flora and has cultural significance to the local Hawaiian people.
